div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.

div.head: Municipalité D'Alexandrie Avis
div.p: Le jour de Samedi, 26 Octobre 1907, la Municipalité procédra a la vente aux enchéres publiques d'une quantité de pierres provenant de la démolition du Jardin Francias et ce a l'emplacement du dit Jardin.
Les pierres sont diviséces en lots de 20 a 100 m3

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'en chére de 1% et déposer le 10% de ka valeur de la marchandise achetée su moment de la vente et effectuer le pairment integral a la Caisse Municipalé le lendermain du jour de l'Adjudi cation

Ils auront a supporter les droits de carriéres au profit de la ville et devront enlever les pierres actietées dans un délai de dix jours sous peine de folle enchére pour compte de l'adjudication quels que soient les prix offerts
Le Vice Président (Signé) Dr. SCHIEST
Alexandrie, le 21 Octobre 1907

div.head: PROGRESS IN AIRSHIPS.
div.p: In the "London Magazine" Dr. Redolf Mar tin, whinee book om "The Age of Airship reviewed in valmns some months ay writes a most optimistic article on the fut f airships Most optimistic, we say. for | evidently did not doabt the saecess of Vi Wellmau's expedition and by this time we « know what happened to that He ip probe! right, however, in thinking that the geners pablie do not realise how mech the sir ha heen already conquered, and that military authorities and state officials do not realise the importance of aerial navigation. He reminds us of Thiers a remark about the first train "The Parisians must have loved this plaything, but it will never carry a traveller or a piece of luggage". Exactly similar remarks are being made to-day about the airship

Dr. Martin seems quite convinced that the airhip is fast tending to become "the most terrible engine of destruction the mind of ma: oan conceive." Pranes, of course, first seized on the ides of airships, apd used balloousin bettie im 1784. In the singe of Patis sixty-five bal loons made an ascent from the town ; but as they were not steerable balloons they were of little use. France, however, then realised he possibilities of ballons, if they were but steer able, and granted a naval engineer 1,600 for the purpose of constructing one. At present France has two battle-airships, the "Lebaudy" (1905) and the "Patrie" (1906) and five in construction , Geermany, of course, not to be behindhand, has had a Prussian aeronact battalion since 1906 busied with the construction of an aérial fleet, and this year a little motor airship, beld by ropes, with two men on board, waa sent up repeatedly by the aéronact battalion at Tegel. It is the mode! of s larger battle-airship, which will be som what of the semi-flexible type of airship of the brothers Lebaedy. The successful ascent of the German battle-airship im July last over Berlin will be remembered. Germany, moreover, pos senses the services of two of the greatest aéronaats—Count von Zeppelin and Major von Parseval. The former has a rigid aleminiam airship, whieh can go at thirty miles an hour agninat the wind , the latter a flexible airship Count von Zeppelin's airship is "the most ter rible engine of aérial warfare yet constructed,' wing able to rain thirty torpedoes of 22 Ibs weight each upon the enemy. Illustrations of all these wondertal airships are The two French battle-eirships are said, on the best authority, to be capable of carrying thirty, and short joumeys even fifty, torpedioe- of more than 22 lbs. each.

The appallingness of war in the age of air ships, the annihilation of frontiers, the sailing mm the air harmless over neutral territory chartered libertinism, in fact, of the new engines of war, and their inexpensiveness ~ompanson with battleships—have been safh mently described already in oar review of Dr Martin's book. What was not so well done in his book was answering the objections usually urged against airships
Objection 1 The airship is easily dispo ed of.

Answer At 2,000 metres it is practically safe from the fire of even heavy artillery At present no one can shoot up to more than 1,50U metres, and only the infantrymea can do this, At present, bowever, gums for aizehip« are being constructed. and cannons for balloons may also be constructed. Dark fog, and cloud moreover, are constantly reckoned upon by airship enthusiasts to come to the aid of the battle-airshipa, and help them unscathed to do untold damage.
Objection 2: Pierce an airship and all is up with it

Answer A single ball carries with it no: great danger for an airship If it should go through the gas balloon of a flexible or sem flexible airship with a capacity of about 3,000 ubtc metres, the aéronauts have still plenty tiwe to retreat with the aitship before it sinks to the ground The gas escapes only ver slowly from the holes made by the bullet.
Moreover, it is decidedly diffienlt to bit an airship
Objection 3 The aerial fleet ix almost use less for battles fought out at sea, as enough henzine cannot be taken

Answer They do not art from a fixed land hase, bat from a movable base —the fleet and small, flexible airships can easily be carried in battleship and inflated on board with compressed gas. The battle-sirship will be part of the equipment of a modern battleship, lke heavy guns. The Zeppelin airship can travel 530 miles and back again without tohing any benzine.
Objection 4. Guns can never be used from the cars owing to the danger of an explosion This is the objection of one of the great aero nautic experts.

Answer: Probably a ngid aluminiom airship could be guaranteed against such danger, in time it will be got over Flexible and sem: flexible airships, having only one gas-bladder, while sleminiom airships have sixteen or missile charged with phosphoras solution would explode the gas envelope. The opposing air ships will, of course, always aim at ripping "p each other's envelopes

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: There are now only seven cases of plagne under treatment in Egypt.

div.head: Fayounn Markets.
div.p: The cattle markets in the Fayoum Province have been reopened from to-day

div.head: A Bank Closed.
div.p: The Banque Melides in Tewfik Pasha street, Alexandria, has closed its doors since Monday last

div.head: Coast Guard Administration.
div.p: The contract for the construction of two motor launches for the Coastguard Adminis tration has been adjudicated to Messrs S. E Saunders & Co. of Cowes, Isle of Wight, England, for the sum of £1,530

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: For the week ending Uctober the 2ist there have been fourteen fatal cases of cattle plague in Egypt, three in the Manfalout district, ten in the Abou Tig district of Assiont, and one in the Abou Kerkas district of Minieh

div.head: Embezzlement
div.p: A Greek contractor of the name of Zuro made an application to the police this morning for the arrest of one of his employes, also a Greek from Fagallah whom he accuses of having embezzled a som of about LE 300 from him. The man has been arrested and the charge will be dealt with shortly.

div.head: The Assault on M. Cloet.
div.p: It is announced that a satisfactory conclu sion has been arrived at in this matter. It will be remembered that Mr. Cloet was violent- ly attacked by an engineer near Rodah Bridge Works, entirely without provocation. M. Cloet's aggressor has now apologised to him 1a most handsome manner and this disagree able incident is thus closed

div.head: Births and Deaths
div.p: From the 15th to the 2ist October there have been 623 births recorded in Cairo, of which 9 were Europeans. For the same period 325 deaths occurred, 14 Eoropeans being in claded in this number, 160 native and 5 of the European deaths being of children under the age of five years. Nine deaths were due to diphtheria, four to typhns and one to measles.

div.head: Canal Clearing
div.p: All the canals in Menoufieh and Gharbie Provinees will be lowered or closed for works in connection with the annual clearances on or about the 10th December, and navigation wil! he diffieult, if not impcasible, from that date until the 25th January next. The Bagourieh canal will be quite impassable. Therefore through navigation from Cairo to Alexandria will only be possible by the river

div.head: Egyptian MS, Stolen.
div.p: There is yet another case reported of robbery from a public collection. Again the Louvre is concerned, though this time the caee is rather one of mysterious disappearance than of ascer tained theft. The lost object is a valuable and beautifully illustrated MS. belonging to the Egyptian Department, and entitled "Le Sera peum de Memphis." It is said to have been lent in an irregular way to the curator of the Belgian Royal Museum for copying.

div.head: The Benha Murder
div.p: At the enquiry into the murder of the wealthy native of Benha, Hag Khadr, which is now proceeding at Zagazig, a woman, living on the murdered man's farm, stated that the crime was committed by Farag Effendi Antoun and his son, who have a farm adjoining She declared that it was due to personal enmity The corpse was discovered fully clad, with watch and chain and other valuables. Antoun and his son have been arrested

div.head: Egyptian Civilisation.
div.p: In the latest namber of the journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute Dr. Bdouard Naville, in a memoir on the origin of Egyptian cvilization, expounds the results of recent excavations as showing that this civilization belongs to a nation formed by an indigenous stock of African origin, among which settled conquerors coming from Arabia. Mr GA & Northoote describes the Nilotie Kavirondo or Jaluo, who inhabit the north eastern shore ot the Victoria Nyanza.

div.head: Public Health Department.
div.p: The following changes and appoitments are announced by the Department of Public Health — Dr. A. H. Brebaut, having com pleted the term of his appointment ax Kesident Medical Officer to the Kasrel Aini Hospital is struck off the strength of the Department from 17th October. Mr. W. Maloney is appoint ed to fill the above appointment at a monthly lary of LE 20,883 from October 17th. Mias Sara Porter has been appointed as nursing sister at the Kasr el Aini Hospital from the 17 October at a monthly salary of LE 9.000.

div.head: False Report
div.p: Our energetic friend the "Lewa" recently gave publicity to a rumour that the Ministry of Public Instruction, was forcing its pupils to take part in the usual physical drill even thongh they were observing the fast of Ramadan, and that such boys as were unable to support the strain were compelled to break the fast in order to continue the exercise The Ministry has this morning issued a full denial of these statements and oor contem porary is once more left to fall back upon the deep store of imagination from which it draws copy wherewith to amuse its readers.

div.head: THE Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p: Will be open during Winter

div.head: KAMEL IN ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: LIBERAL LEADER'S TELEGRAM.

At the very moment when Mustapha Pasha Kamel was about to begin bis speech at the Zitipia Theatre on Tuesday, the following tele gram was banded to him from Mohamed Bey Wahid, the leader of the Egyptian Liberal Party, who dispatched it from Helouan —

In the name of the beloved fatherland and of the holy faith which you make use of in order to spread abroad falsehood and confusion, and which are witnesses against our vileness ; in the name of freedom and of uprightness, whereby you are onmasked and shown to the world in your true colours , I herewith accuse you, at the very time when yoo would display your cunning and your raseality, of being simply « vile imposter, ali those in Egypt, who are men of anderstanding, hold you to be blemish and a creature of illomen for this land. They know that you are a traitor to your country, an enemy of your fellow. i arged on by evil, paid to praise the methods of slavery, despotism, decadence and worse ills, which you cloke beneath the names of freedom and faith. You and your lies are only believed in by the brawlers, the fools, and men, who have lost their posts and by those whose base- ness is notorious. May God fight you and me. He will show to all Egyptians the right road to peace, whereby they will be able to gain the trust of the Retormers, which is the sole and and only lasting good of Egypt.
(Signed). The humble servant of the Father land, Wahid

div.head: PASSENGERS FOR EGYPT.
div.p: London, Thursday.
The Duke of Devonshire and party, Lady Gorst, and Lady Melllwraith are sailing for Egypt by the S.S. "Caledonia

div.head: A SEAMEN'S QUARREL.
div.p: MURDER OF ENGLISH FIREYMAN

Two Englishmen, of the names of Cannon and King, employed as firemen aboard the oil tank S.S. "Baku Standard', had a hot dispute at 1.30 this morning over a chank of tobacco, which resulted in morder. Cannon, losing all control over himself, snatched up a knife and attacked King violently and after a few minutes struggle succeeded in drawing the knife across his companion''s neck The officer on watch on arrival at the scere of the fight foond that King was dead, his head having been almost completely severed from the body, and after communication wth the Customs police Cannon was placed under arrest and was this morning taken in handcuffs t the British Consulate for examination King's body was conveyed to the Government hospital, The "Baku Standard" arrived yes terday moming from Constanza and Kavak onder the *command of Captain Steward The local agents for the steamer are Messrs Worms and Co

div.head: EGYPTIAN MAIL STEAMSHIP CO. LTD
div.p: The S.S. "Heliopolis," the first steamer of thie line, bas already been booked almost ful! np for its first sailing fiom Marseilles on the 7th December and is due to arrive at Alex andria on the 11th of that month. The report which had gained currency in Paris of the com bine of the new line to Egypt with the Ham burg American Line is incorrect. It is true, however, that arrangements have been made with the Hamburg Line which are expected to prove eminently satisfactory from the point of view of both companies and the travelling public. The Egyptian Mail Steamship Company have incorporated the Hamburg-American service in their improved service, and German boats« will no longer run in the Mediterranean, but the Egyptian mail steamers still remain British boats manned by British officers and men, and owned and governed from London

div.head: MILITARY NOTES
div.p: Captain J. A. Byrne, 2nd Bo. Royal Inms killing Pusiliers, has reterned from leave.
Lt A. P. Evans, Ist Bo. K. RR Corpa, has been granted extension of leave until November 20.

The death is announced of Colonel Arthar Fitz Gerald, formerly of the Bengal Army. He served with the Bhutan expedition of 1865, the Abyssinia expedition of 1868, in the Afghan war of 1879, and with the Sudan expedition of 1885

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman liner 'Sardinia' sailed from Tripoli (Barbary) last evening and is due at Alexandria on Saturday evening or early on Sunday morning.
The S.S. "Imperial Prince' and S.S. "Khafir Prince", with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 23rd inst. and are dne to arrive at Alexandria on Sunday

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI.
div.p: ENGLISH AND CAIRO BOARDS

An extraordinary general meeting of Wal- ker and Meimarachi, Limited, called in pur- snance of a requisition made by certain share- holders, was held on the 17th Oct. 1907 at Salsibury House, Finsbury-circus

At the commencement of the meeting Mr. J.E. Drower took the chair. Before the pro ceedings commenced, however, Mr. Carton de Wiart objected to Mr. Dowers presiding, and claimed that he himself was chairman of the company. It was true, he said, that a portion of the board, at a meeting to which neither of the Egyptian members was called, declared, on a technicality, that he was no louger qualified to be a director, or, therefore, technicality no longer existed, and therefore he thought he was ipso facto reinstated as chairman.
After some discussion Mr. Drower consented to an independenr gentleman being appointed and Mr. W. T. Western, on being asked, co sented to preside.

The Chairman said the meeting had done him the honour to pvt him in s very diffeult position. He was not pecuniarily interested to a large extent, bet he represented one or more of the largest shareholders, and last year, at their request, he went to Cairo, and there had the opportunity of making himself acquainted with some of the persons who had charge of the business.
The Secretary (Mr. H.C. Hood) having read the notice.

Mr. Rau moved the first resolution - "That it is desirable to adjust the differences between the English and the Egyptian members of the board as speedily as may be." He complained that the board had refused to receive amend- ments of which notice had been given, and then went on to express disapproval of the board having, a few days ago, elected George Walxer to fill the vacancy in number. He dealt at some length with the disagreements which had arisen between the London directors and those in Egypt, which had as long as a year ago led the London directors to change the whole basis on whieh the basiness was started ten years ago. It was started on the fact that it was M. Meimarachi's business, and, bet for bis hame, many would not bave subscribed. The London directors about eighteen months ago superseded Mr Meimarachi as managing director without informing the shareholders, and no information was given to the shareholders even at the last general meeting, though after the meeting there was a sort of informal commanication. He urged that in consequence of the action of the board in depriving the business of its snccessful head the trade showed onmistakable signs of falling off. It was urgently mecessary that Mr Meimarachi should be reinstated.
Mr. Macandrew seconded the resolution, and said that im all bis experience he had never found more well-grounded causes for complaint
Mr Javal asked when Mr. Walker was ap pointed director
The Chairman read the minutes, which showed that on September 20 last Mr. Walker was appointed, subject to his acquiring the necessary qualification
In answer to further questions it was stated that Mr Walker had since acquired the shares bet there had been no further resolution of the board with regard to his appointment.

Mr. Barrington said that ander Article 80 the directors should only appoint "a qualified member As Mr. Walker was not then qoalifi led, and he had not been appointed since jobtaiming his qualification, he (the speaker held that the appointment wes illegal
Mr. Payne (solicitor to the company), being Jasked for his opinion, replied "I do not think he is a director of the company."

Mr Barton Kent said he was elected a di rector a little overs year ago. The beginning of all the trouble was the decision not to Jreappoint Mr Meimarachi as managing director when bis term of office expired in Joly last He entered the board with a perfectly open mind. He began to work very hard for peace, and did his best to bring matters to satisfactory Jeonclusion, when at a board meeting in Sep- tember last the London directors (Mr. Drower, Mr Laning, and himself) agreed that Mr Meimarachi was to retarn as director to Cairo, as chairman of the committee of management but, unfortunately, when Mr. Meimarachi got back that agreement was not carrried out. It taen became practically impossible to go on as they were. He suggested the appointment of a committee of shareholders to investigate the differences that existed, and moved an amend ment to that effect
Mr. Harrison said he was a resident of Cairo, aod was acquainted with the circomstances. The suggestion made was a good one, and he would second it.

Mr. Barrington opposed the amendment, which he characterised as a "death bed repen tance and conteasion." It was too late now to appoint a committee as the busy season in Egypt was approaching, and the trouble would not be cleared up in time to present its effect on the season's business
Mr. Rau said that whatever changes were made mast be made st once, or they would lose the season, and a committee of inquiry would mean delay.

Mr. Barton Kent objected to the tern "death bed repentance," and reminded the meeting that the London board did take some ot the principal shareholders into their conf- dence at a conference which was held on May 16 last

Mr. Nungovich said that for the last ten years he had been a friend to the company, and two years ago he was induced to buy shares for £90,000, which were only really worth on the market £50,000. A sum of £1,500 was voted to hime by the Cairo direction, and after some time the London directors said that is washeld to be illegal. He had always been, and was now, ready to return the money if he was advised that it was illegal. Under his agreement with the company he held that he was entitled to it as brokerage.

Mr. Drower said that the auditors of the company refused to pass the payment, and the directos asked for the money to be returned, on the ground that no brokerage could be paid except that was set forth in the prospectus.
Mr. Nungovich said the prospectus could not over-ride his contract with the company
The ammendment was put to the meeting and lost, 17 voting for 28 against
The orginal resolution was then carried unanimonsly.
Count de Germainy moved: "That it is desir able to secure again the services of Mr. C. G. Meimarachi as general manager in Egypt, with a seat on the board".
Mr. Adams seconded the resolution.

The Chairman in answer to a question as to what view he formed when he went to Cairo, sadi he came to the conclusion, that Mr. Meimarachi was an admirable salesman and manager of his department, but that it would be better to have someone else in financial control of the company. He thought th financial control should be in the hands of the principal shareholders, and as these were in England, London was the proper place for lay ing down the roles under which the managers should act.
'The resolution, on being pot to the meeting, was carried nem. con.

Mr. Strong proposed : "That it be a regula tion of the company, prescribed by it in this meeting, that, until after the next ordinary general meeting, no casual vacancy be filled up by the directors, except by the appointment of persons approved by this meeting, and thta Mr. C. G. Meimarach be approved accord ingly."
Mr. Drower objected to Mr. Meimarachi be ing appointed a directo, and after some further discussion, the resolution was carried nem. con.
Mr. Rau said he took it for granted that Mr Walker was not a director now
The Chairman said that question was not before them.

Mr. Drower said that if it was found that Mr. George Walker was not a director then they were bound to elect Mr. Meimarachi at the next meeting. They were not going to elect anyove else in face of the decision of that meeting. They would take legal opinion as to the position with regard to Mr. Walker
The meeting then terminated

div.head: The Hailstorm
div.p: The damage done by the hailstorm yesterday was more serious than was at first known. Not only were there many windows broken, bat the roofs of many houses sadly need repair The weather to day is cold and windy

div.head: THE PORT SAID INCIDENT
div.p: To The Editor or The "Egyptian Gazette"

Dear Sir,—Your Port Said correspondent tells os that a dragoman of that town has distinguished himself by dragging and outrag ing a young English woman paying 4 visit to the town from one of the steamers in the harbour. He also informs us that the said dragoman was at large and well the day after his exploit. It the story be true this latter fact does not say mach for the protection afforded to our women by the aathorities or for the spirit of the British Colony of Port Said
Yours truly, Caraene
Turf Club, Cairo, October 23rd.

div.head: CAIRO TO HELOUAN.
div.p: To the editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir- Having read with some intrest the various letters that have been appearing of late in the columns of your popular paper under the above heading, I beg leave to add a few remarks, which occur to me from the onlookers point of view

To start with, there are many solid factors why the Government should turn a more kindly eye to Helouan than it has done during the last decade. Surely its population of say approximately 5,000 in the summer, and of 12,000 in the winter season, is enough in itself to command some consdierationfrom the de partmental decrees, whereas the miserable pit tance of some L.E. 2,000 per annum which the Tanzim Department now have to cover all ex penditure incidental to the town of Helouan is ludicrously inadequate for a town that boasts of fine houses and many rich inhabitants.

The laying out of Helouan was so well cared for in the first instance with its 20 metre road space all over, to say nothing of its general cleanliness, quite apart from its geogrpahical advantages over all other places in Egypt, led the inhabitants to hope that when the time comes for developing Cairo city's environs, that Helouan would be the first claimant and the first to recieve such benefits as the Govern ment had to bestow, therefore it is in no way surprising to find that bitter discontent reigns and rankles in the minds of many of the oldest inhabitants, when they look round and see that other and newer suburban areas, are re cieving a full complement of favour from the powers, while they nad their attract ive town are totally ignored. The backing that the heliopolis Oasis company has recieved from the Government is only a bone of conten tion that ranks equally with the project for connecting up Ghezireh district by construct ing a very costly bridge across the Nile within half a mile of the existing bridge, thus creating and inaugurating new suburbs, the popularity of which being problematic, inasmuch is it has yet to be proved, while Helouan's po pularity cannot be gainsaid after an existence and steadily continuing growth, without a shimmer of official favour, over a period of some fifteen years.

Further, and with much reason, the inhabi tants of Helouan considered themselves ne- gleoted indeed, when some two to three years ago the Delts Light Railways were given » concession to work the line of railway from their terminus to the capital, which has onl: led to greater dismay as time advances, how can as system, which was initiated and brought into existence for the needs transport of merchandise in the interior of Egypt, by menas of a narrow gauge line, reconcile itslef to the requirements of a broad gauge passenger traffic over a matter of 95 kilometres; that it cannot, has been amply proved of inte, by the fact of its rolling stock conmstently failing to meet the demands made upon it, for it is an every day occarvence that the axle bomes get hot after every two journeys made by its new 1906 coaches, and there are none to replace them , the result being that many intending visitors to Heloean, decide on some other locality, simply and solely for the reason that thé train service is made too utterly disagreeable, furthermore the cousins and friends of the local inhabitants, who may be Jiving at Zeitown or elsewhere on the Matarieh line, point with derision at their less fortunate Helouan aquaintances, boasting as they do of their express, and 15 minutes service on the ESR; where every thing possible is done for the comfort and |pleine convenence of passengers

Had the ESR taken over the Helouan section of rail from the Snares group, there would not have been the continous outcry that has prevailed, with what one mast re luctantly admit too real justification, nor would there be need now for the "Sop to Cerberus" held out to the Helouan public, that the line will be electrified. This of course means time in any case, but with the Delta Light Railways it means much time, and time to spare, meanwhile the stem of the tide is stayed and warded off from Helowan in the matter of advance in p polarity as far as possible, for thé extremely simple reason that transit i# so fobtase a question, which the several suggéstions for « road would some what mitigate against the fragrant neglect. not to speak of wrongs, that Helouan has saf- fered from.

In order to achieve some better method of commenication than what already exists, many of the residents have expressed their willing- ness, if the Government will make some more, to asmst in either defraying some considerable proportion of the cort of a vehicular highway, or else towards the upkeep of same, which would not be onerous when the number of inhabitants is taken into consideration. That in days to come difficalties for the construction of a road will not decrease, isa matter for the Ministry to ponder over, and when all is said and done who woald be the greater gainer. The answer admitted by al! and every is Cairo town.
I am Sir, Yours, etc. "Onlooker."

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: Princess Henry of Battenburg visited last Thursday the Modern Gallery, New Bond street, and made a selection from Mr. Lam plough's drawings of Egypt.

SIr William Garstin has not as yet coem to any decision as to the date of his departure from Egypt. Nothing definite has as yet been settles as to who will be his successor, but the general opinion in offical circles is that Mr. Dupuis is the favorite for the post and is backed by the Sudan Government
Sir Joseph Saba Pasha, K.C.M.G, left yes terday for Cairo by the evening express
Sir T. Forwell Buxton is coming out to Egypt this week, and will remain here for several weeks
We are sorry to learn that Chataway Bey has broken his arm, the accident being due to a fall from his bicycle

Lewa Mansfield Pasha, Commandant of the Cairo police, who was decorated with the order of Chevalier of the Leion of Henoar, by the French Republic on the occasion of the 14th of July fete, has recieved the insignia of the order
Herr von Dernburg, the German Colonial Minister, is arriving at Suez this evening from his trip to the German Colonies in East Africa. He will come on to Cairo

It is possible that Mr. Garofallo, Cheirf of the Forwarding Office at the Cairo Post Offices will be appointed Mamour of Port Said Post Office. The appointment of Mr. Garofallo has, howeverm not be settled

Among the visitos staying ay the San Stefano Casino are COl. and Mrs. Cox, Mus tapha Pasha Kame, Mr. and Mrs. Ford, Mr. and the Misses Pagnon, Mr. ALbert Schwander, Mr.,Mrs.,and Miss Khoury, Judge G. and Miss Batcheller, Mr. Nicolas Kindinon, Mr. H.F.C. Parkinson, Mr. L.S. Gore. Mr. Biad Sabe, Said Effendi ALi, Mr. A. de Korlmida Capt. Gray, Mr. Basile Gorra, Mrs. Downing, Dixon Bey, Mr. A.K. Lewis, Mr. MacQueen, Mrs.Koch, and the Col. Ropert. Thre are al ready a good many bookings for later in the season, this being the first time the Casino re mains open in winter.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA'BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi)

Decidément ca ne va pas en Amérique et la dépression des valeurs américaines, nous di sent les dépéches de oe matin, aflectent tout a Londres. On pense que la Banque d'Angle terre élévera demain son taux d'escompte. En attendant le taux privé vient d'étre augmenté de 4 1/2 a 458%.

Avec de pareilles nouvelles et le fléchisee ment des valeurs égyptiennes au Stock Ex change, on concoit que notre marché ait été défavorablement impressionné, au lendemain surtout d'une tenue locale déja passablement équivoque. Aussi aton ouvert ce matin en pleine débandade sur les titres actuellement en vouge, pour se raffermir tant soit pen verc la fin, mais en aloturant tout de meme a un niveau inférirur a celui d'hier. Des transac tions, unpeu plus nobreuses et plus impor tantes, quoique toujours limitées, ont pu étre effectuées a la faveur d'une réduction dans les prix. C'est ainsi qu'il a été vendu quelques paquets de Delta Land, de Comptoir et de Cassa di Scouto. Les valeurs dirigeantes ont été négligées, exxepité l'Agricole qui a été échangeée en petite proportion

A signaler encore quelques affaires en Khe divial Mail. Certains détenteurs qui avaient tenu bon jusqu'a présent ont cru le moment venn de liquider. Le cours fléchit pour ce motif de 23/3 8 28/. vendears. Quand avec cele nous sarons noté une petite demande en Marketa, nous aurons résamé 4 pea prés tout ce que la aéance a offert d'intéréssant.
Plusieurs antres titres ont subi une dépré ciation a cause d'offre de vente qui, d'ailleurs, n'ont en général pas eu de résultat
L'Agricole rétrograde de 8 1/4 a 8 3/32, la National Bank de 21 18/16 4 21 9/16, la Delta Light de 10 1/4 4 10 8/16, et les Lote Tures de 163 a 162.

En baisse également les actions de capital Faux du Caire de 111 a 110 les Nungovich Hotels de 17 3'84 17 1/4, le Cheikh de 95 90 fr, l'Urbaine de 33/44 8 5/8 vendears, le Comptoir de 3 1/8 a 2 31/32 l'ancienne, de 3 3/16 a 3 1/16 la nouvelle et de 2 1/8 a 2 1/16 le fondateur, le Crédit Franco-Rgyptien de 4 1/4 a 4 3/16, et la Banque d'Orient de 119 a 117 1/2

Parmi les valeurs de moindre enverguge, les Markets seuls reprennent de 25/6 a 26/-. Yons les autres changements indiquent une moins value: la Cass di Sconto recule de 50 1 49 1/2, la Delta Land de 1 7/16 a 1 3/8, les Bucreries de 35 a 38, L'Investment de 7/16 a 13/32, les Estates de 9/16 a 1/2, la Building LAnds de 2 1/8 a 2 1/16, l'action Allotment de 2 1/8 a 2, et la Levant de 17/32 a 1/2

Sur le reate de la cote il n'y a pas de change ment a signaler. Oa voit que les fluctastions déntotent pour les valuers abordées une dépres sion générale. Et malheureusument rien dans la situation présent ne parmet de prévoir a
bref délai le mouvement de reprise que nous attendene de Londres et dont norte place aurait tant besoin pour se soutenir et se relever.

Hier a 4 h. p.m. les administarteurs de l'U nited et les créanciers de la dite société pour les terrains de l'ile de Rodah (57 feddans) se sont réunisaux bureaux de MM Carver Bros & Co. pour discuter sur les bases d'un arran gement. Les administrateurs de l'United ont finni par acceptar toutes les conditions des créan ciers, de sorte qu'il n'y a plus a l'avenir de conflit a redouer.

D'aprés le journal l'"Information" de Paris, les bénéficies nets des Sucreries et de la Raffi nerie d'Egypt pendant l'exercice qui va entre clos le 31 octobre, s'éléveraient a environ 50,000 liv. st. aprés le service des obligations hypothécaires 5%. COmme ces obligations représentent un montant de 20 millions de frances et sont amortissables seulement a partir de 1910, on peut en déduine que le bénéfice net industriel, tous frais généranx déduits, serait de quelques 2 millions 250,000 francs.

div.head: Circulaire B. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES BT CRITIQUES
Le Caine, Mercredi 28 Octobre.
Le taux de l'escompte libre & Londres est renseigné invarié & 4 1/2 pour cent.
Au Stock-Exchange, le Consolidé anglais s'est maintens hier 4 83 3/8. L'Unifiée a été forme a 102 1/4. Permes t la National Bank 4 22, l'Agricole a 8 3/8,la Daria a 13 3/4 ot la Delta Light a 10 3/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a été soutene a 692. La Banque d'Athénes a gagné 1 franc. Les Lots Tures se sont raffermis & 168.

Ici, Jes liquidations forcées continuent a peser sur le marehé qui bien qu'en meilleure tendance ne peut engager une reprise sérieuse par suite des ventes imtempestives que l'on continue a opérer sana ménagements. A vrai dire, on peut étre satiaisit. de le stance de ce matis. Elle a continué la sonsolidation com mencée hier et a vu une animation suivie sur un certain nombre de titres en meme temps qu'angmentaient les achats
A n'en pas douter, il suffirait d'une nouvelle hausse de nos titres a Londres pour que norte marché se mette a la remorque et que la cote enregistre des plus-values sensibles

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na tional Bank se relévelégérement a 21 3/4-13/16. Le Cassa di Seonto 4 60. Le Comptoir Pimanciér et Commercial hansse 4 3 1/16-1/8 et Ia fondateur Société Générale inne retombe & 39. Las H. de Vries and tigny Ltd. tres animées ont d'importantes ftuctua- tions, ce qui ne les empéche pas de cloturer a peu prés invarides' ser hier. La fondateor Banque de Reports accentue sa reprise a 3 1/2.

La Delta Light est plus faibles 10 1/4 Les Jouissances Eaux du Qnire reculent a 189. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est en progrés a 690-691 ainsi que son obligation nonvelle & 258-854. La fondatenr Allotment fidchit P.T. 56. L'Enterprise and Development n'est pas mieux tenuea 8 3/8. Les fondateurs Entre prises et Travaux concentrent l'animation de la séance at haussent P.T. 41. L'American Nile progresse a 2 7/16-1/2

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land est plus active a 1 7/16 achesteur. La New Egyp tain s'alourdit a 12/9-13/-. Les Estates resent a 0 9/16 et leur part fléchit a 3. Les Cotton Mills descendent a 1/6 et l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail poursuit ses progrés a 22/6. Les Oasis (Western Egypt) se traltent a 0 7/16.

Nous extrayons du "Bulletin Mensuel du Commerce extérieur de l'Egypte" que putlie la Direction des donanes, les chiffres suivants, qui montrent éloquemment que la crise n'a eu qu'an trés minime effet sur l'état général cle notre commerce

Durant te mois de Septembre 1907 la valeur totale des importations s'est leyée a L. E 2,081,047 contre LE 2,097,768 pendant le méme mois en 1906, ce qui montre une dimi nation de L.B 66,721. Par contre, durant les neuf premiers mois de année les importa tions acensent une aagmentation de LR 1,988,479.
Quant aux exportations, elles se sont dlevees pendant le mois dernier A LE. 1,045,778 con tre LE. 908,336 en 1906 soit en augmentatior te LE. 187,442
Do ler Janvier au 80 Septembre, l'augmen tation totale des exportations se chiffre par LE. 2,759,205.

Si l'on compare ces chiffres, on voit des l'a bord que malgré les difficultés monétaires et la crise de crédit dont noug sonffrons encore, l'E gypte a considérablement accru son commerce d'exportation, ce qui dénote une augmentation de productiyité, de natare dcombler en une certgine mesyre les déficits Iaissés par la crise D'antre part, et c'est on indice oopamique qui 4 son importance, elle a diminué notablement ses importantion, d'ou il résulte que ses enga gements étaxt rédgits, tandis que ses créances ont augmenté, rétablit ainsi parla force des choses une "balance des comptes" en sa faveur.

Il faut noter de plus que le mouvement de cotons, a la date indiquée plus haut, n'avait pas encore commencé, at que oatte différence en favour de l'Egypté ne fera que a'accentuer durnat le darnier trimestre
SI l'on ajoute a cela, les sommes que nous apporteront les touristes cet hiver, on peut raisonnablement prévoir une amélioration de la situation générale dans un avenir prochain.
On li dans "l'Information de Paris":

On dit de bonne source, que les bénéfices neta des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypté pendamé l'excercise qui va entre eles le 31 Octo bre, s'elé veraient a environ 50,000 liv st aprés le service de obligations hypothécaires 5%. Comme ces obligations représentent un mon tant de 20 milliond de fraces et sont emortis sables seulement a partir de 1910, om peut eu déduire que le bénéfice net industriel, tous frais généraux déduits serait de quelque 2,250,000 francs
Il serait prudentd'attendre une confirmation officielle
Carnet de l'actionaire

MM. les actionaires de "The Auto-Grage and Auto-Cabs Cy. Ltd." sont informés que le Conseil d'Administraion a décidé l'appel du 4me et dernier versement de £1 du sur les actions. Le paiement doit etre effectué au siége social au Caire avenue de Boulac, au plus tard le 30 Novembre 1907
Intérée=sts de retard 9% l'an

MM. les actionaires de "l'Anglo-Egyptian Finance and Exchange Cy, Ltd." sont avisés que le Conseil d'Administration a décidé de proroger jusqu'au 5 mai 1908, l'époque de la déchéance primitiyement fixée au 5 Novembre 1907, a l'encontre des actions non entiément libérées a la date du 20 Septembre 1907. Les retardataires resteut tenus au paiement des intérets a raison de 9% l'an.

div.head:
THE MOROCCAN SITUATION.
A SERIOUS FIGHT

div.p: The reconnaissance of 2ist instant was a serious fight. The French were sixty Moors when they were encountering 5,000 of Mulay Hafid's troops. General Drade's arrival and the assistance of the warships averted a disaster. ( Reuter )
M. Regnault bas informed Ben Sliman that France would authorise a first advance to the Maghzen in order to meet the pressing expen ses Ben Sliman thanked him heartily. (Havas)

The Kuickerbocker Trust Company has sus pended payment. The announcement caused the worst demoralisation for months. Stocks were thrown over regardless of value. The Mayer Company, New York Stock-brokers has failed for 6,000,000 dollars. The Treasury bas ordered 6,000,000 dollars of Government leposits to be distribated among the leading National Banks bere. The demoralisation is retlected in the grain market. An enormous liquidation of Chicago wheat has taken place.

President Roosevelt, speaking at Nashville, lenied that he was responsible for the crisis He had turned on the light and was not res ponsible for what was revealed. He would unswervingly persevere in his policy. (Reuter)
The American slump is dominating the mar ket here and affecting everything. It is expect ed that a rise in the hank rate will take place to-morrow (Reuter)

div.head:
BRITAIN''S FOREIGN POLICY.
THE PREMIER'S OPINIONS

div.p: Sir H. C. Bannerman, speaking at Donferm line, said that Great Britain's foreign relations were never abler or more successfully managed than by Sir E Grey. The Government had thrown its whole energies on the side of peace, amity, and arbitration and disclaimed all bos tility or aggression towards its neighbours The agreement with Russia had been the avowed policy of the Liberals for 15 years (Reuter)

div.head:
GREEKS AND BULGARIANS
GREEK VILLAGE BURNT

div.p: It is semi-offerally announced that a large Bulgarian band has completely destroyed the Greek village Rakovan near Monastir, borning 121 houses. The villagers fled terrorstricken Since 2ith Aagust 18 Greeks bave been killed in sansdjak of Serres. of Rakovan has inceased the people and reprisals are ex peeteri (Reuter)

div.head:
THE SHREWSBURY DISASTER.
THE JURY'S VERDICT

div.p: The coroners jury has given a verdict that the Shrewsbury disaster was due to ineffecent brakepower
According to a telegram recieved from Teheran the Shah has signed a decree dismis sing the Cabinet (Reuter)

div.head:
WRECK OF STEAMER.
ALL PASSENGERS SAVED.

div.p: The Hamborg-America steamer "Borussia" from Brazil while coaling here in a strong tide listed, foundered, and disappeared. The pas sengers were saved. three of the crew are mis- sing (Reuter)

div.head:
EARTHQUAKE IN CALABRIA.
PANIC OP INHABITANTS

div.p: Violent earthquake shocks were felt yester- day evening in Calabria throughout the region stricken in 1905, and also Messina. The damage done is slight but the inhabitants are panic stricken and are camping in the open (Reuter)
The discussion on the arbitration between the Porte and the Ottoman Railway Company will begin on the 31st inst (Hawas)
The Emperor is getting on very well and he worked this morning (Havas)
The King of Hellenes has arrived. (Reuter)

div.head: The Money Market.
div.p: Up till last Friday evening it was quite ex pected that the amount of the shipment of gold to Egypt on Natorday would exceed a million, and some surprise was expressed when it was found that less than six hundred thousand, viz, £590,000, was withdrawn for that quarter
No definite information is to band as to the exact extent of tomorrow's probable with drawal tor Egypt, but we understand that it will be under half a million

The smallness of the above-mentioned ex port, last week and the sobsequent action of the India Council in re lending pr mnptly the £1,000,000 which had been paid by the Bank of Indian Bills, gave a very easy tone to the money market, and the supplies of floating credit were further increased by th release of a certain amount of dividend money. On Tuesday short loans were offered down as low as 2 per cent

During the latter part of the week, however the market has developed a firmer tone, large ly due to the Bank removing money from Lombard Street with the object of making their official discount rate more effective. Yesterday three months' bills hardened to 4%.

The bank return this week makes a much more satisfactory showing. In consequence of the return of money from the provinces, the reduction in the reserve is limited Lo £300,000, notwithstanding a withdrawal of nearly £800,000 for export. The reserve is now £23,837,000 as compared with £18,862,000 in the corresponding wekk last year. The Proportion of reserve to habilities in 2 7/8% higher on the week, being now 49 3/8%. Last year the "Proportion" was only 37 3/4%.
The price for gold is now 7710 1/2

div.head: Silver
div.p: The silver market has estimated depressed, and the quotation for immediate delivery gave way further yesterday to 28, 1/16 per ounce, although this is not the lowest touched since out last, as early in the week it marked 27 1/8.

div.head: The Stock Markets.
div.p: Each day the passes seems to bring increased trouble for the Stock Exchange, and the de pression now ruling in nearly all sections is acute. The chied destributing influence during the past week has again been the New York market. The financial position in Wall Street seems to hvae become increasingly strained, and considerable nervousness is felt as to the ultimate outsome of the trouble. In some quar ters a crisis would be welcomed, as it felt that this would do much to clear the at- mosphere.

Yesterday the depression was further ac centuated by the announcement of the failure at Hambarg of an old-establisbed bani, whose liabilities are said to exosed Vie the exception of the stocks gave way all-round The business done was only on a small scale, but the markets are in such a nervous condition that the slightest adverse influence has the effect of immediately putting prices still lower

div.head: Consols
div.p: The steadline of the gilt-edged section is about the only satisfactory feature in the markets. Consols were rather weak at the beginning, but have since been firm, and close last night at 82 5/8 for the account. In view of the depression ruling in other quaters, this firmenessof first-class securities is somewhat significant. To-day consols have advanced 1/2

div.head: Foreign Bonds
div.p: The market for international stocks has moved irregularly. The feature has been the firmness of Russians. Although the Fives gave way 1/4 yesterday, all the stocks are appreciably higher on balance. To-day Russian Fours are down 1/4
Japanese have been weak, and on balance show declines of about a point, the 2nd series having shed 1 3/8 up to last night. Japanese have been firmer to-day. The 2nd 4 1/2 are 3/8 better.

div.head: Home Rails
div.p: The Council of the Railway Companies Association has now definitely declined to meet the men's official in conference, and the next development of the orisis is being awaited with no little anxiety. Appeals are being made to the Government from certain quarters to intertere to prevent a strike, but so far Mr Lioyd George, the President of the Board of Trade, has refused to take any steps im the matter Meanwhile the ballot of the men is proceeding, bot the result will not be known antil about the end of the month.

With feeling at such a tension, the present flatness of the market for railway shares is quite natural. It would be futile to expect investors to have any dealings with this section antil the crisis is past. "The Times" in a leading article to-day says there will not be a general strike in which we quite agree. Another depressing feature this week had been the terrible disaster on the North Western Railway at Shrewsbury. The shares of this company were last night quoted down 131}. Last Priday they left off at 135. Great Western were also three points lower on the week at 114

div.head: Americans
div.p: The effect of the critical financial position in New York on American shares here has not been so marked as might have been sapposed The reason is that operators in London have during recent months shown more disinelina tion to deal in these stocks, the resalt being that at the present time the American account is very small

For the greater part of the week the market has been quiet and fairly steady. Yesterday it fell in sympathy with the break in Wall Street, but later recovered At the close Unions were down 14 at 1214, Sonthern Pacific 15/8 at 75, and Milwaukee 3 116 1/2. Southern Pacific closed 1 higher at 49 .To-day Americans have improved. Unions have advanced 2 1/2

div.head: Egyptians
div.p: After keeping firm daring the first part of the week, the tone for Egyptians was yesterday not so satistactory, and prices in most cases off For instance, National Banks after being 294 at the commencement, were offered last even ing at 21,1516 Agriecaltural Bank remained firm at §, 7/16, at which price they 'hanged hands To-day National close at 214-4 and Agnoultural at 8, 5/16-7/16. Agnealtural Preference are good at 94 Agricaltaral Rank 34°, Debentures are down to 81-3, and no buyers about Delta Land and investment have been weak and closed last night at 1 $4 They leave off today at 1} §. Delta Prefe rence Bearer, after being ap to 10, 11/16, were yestetday down agaim to 104 They close 1044 United Egyptian Lands are offered at 6/« but there is no business doing in them, and the best bid is about 5/s Deira Sanieh close 18 4 14, and the Deferred nominally 71-5 At 1116 there were yesterday large sellers about of Egyptian Eetates, but the market is extremely limited now in all the low priced shares

New Egyptians are quoted 9 16-11/16 and, Corporation of Western Egypt 1/2 5/8. Egyptian Markets are 27/6—28 6 ex-dividend, and Salt and Soda are about 186. There has not been any business doing in Land Bank of Union Fonciere, and the prices are quoted 74 and }-4 respectively

div.head: Mining
div.p: The South African market has been favour ably influenced by the optimistic statement made by Mr. J. B. Robinson regarding the prospects of the mining industry. Mr. Rebin- son in an interview said that the Transvaal Government is determined to assist the indus try, and were anxious that further mines should start work. Ievestors, he said, might rest assured that nothing would be wanting in the efforts of the Government to their interesta, as well as the general welfare of the country
Several of the leading shares have improved, although Rhodesians have been dull
Yesterday the market was somewhat affected by the weakness of the COntinental Bourse
There is nothing new to say with refrence to the Egyptian mining descriptions

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB
div.p: REGATTA
Class I
Class II
Rating Class

The wind was very fresh and gusty yesterday and kept veering between W. and W.N W and as there was a rather heavy sea outside it was decided by the officer of the day that Class 11 should race inside the harbour which they did, vie Course K. A good race in this class was witnessed between the Cattelaya and Akraba.

In the rating class, as will be seen by the above resalts the Ananké only beat the Banshee || by 27 seconds on time allowasce but the Ananké carried away one of her port shroads which must have delayed ber coo siderably before it was made fast again. The Maltese Cross would no doubt have won if she had not started 5 minutes late and run into the Gumrook soon after the start
In Class I the Delikanti came in an easy first, probably due to the strong breeze which always suits her.
